Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Commercialization of an Enzymatic Method for Biofilm Removal
Award.AbstractNarration:
Bacteria have evolved a wide range of strategies to adhere to and grow on metallic and other physical surfaces. Disease causing bacteria produce a protective coating, known as biofilm, which shields the bacteria from chemical treatments while at the same time allowing them to attach to these physical surfaces. This has a major economic and health impact on manufacturing of packaged foods, pharmaceuticals and consumer goods as well as medical devices. A specific example is the health impact of foodborne illnesses caused by bacteria in the United States, where the estimated cost in terms of medical treatments, loss of work, resultant disability and mortality is at least $55 billion a year. Furthermore, preventing bacterial contamination throughout the food manufacturing process presents several unique challenges. While both industry and government agree that a solution to the increasing number of infections from food products is required, 'poultry processors have resisted, arguing that it would be expensive and ultimately futile, because Salmonella is so pervasive.' Thus, an effective solution to this and other similar challenges must (1) provide broad activity against a wide range of bacterial pathogens due to their prevalence throughout the manufacturing process and (2) do so in a cost-effective manner compatible with current manufacturing processes.

This I-Corps team has developed a series of engineered enzymes, which are biological molecules that exhibit broad biofilm-degrading activity against a wide range of microbial biofilms. The enzymes retain activity in the presence of common additives used in commercial disinfectants, making them suitable as biocompatible disinfectants in food, pharmaceutical and other manufacturing processes. The proposed technology directly addresses a critical, unmet need to improve water quality, food safety, multi-drug resistance and thus well being of society through the development of enzyme-based technologies that can remove biofilm, which is a major factor that contributes to multidrug resistance and persistence. The I-Corps program will enable the team to identify an effective cost per use, which is key in benchmarking the effectiveness of the proposed approach relative to current enzyme technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: Bacteria have evolved a wide range of strategies to adhere to metallic and other abiotic surfaces, which has a major economic and health impact on sterile manufacturing and packaging of food, pharmaceuticals and consumer goods. In particular, 1 in 6 people will experience food-borne illness, and the total number of food-borne illnesses reported is on the rise. One major cause for the increased number of food-borne illnesses is the ability of microbial pathogens such as Salmonella and Listeria to adapt to common chemical cleaning procedures, thereby gaining resistance and persisting in food products and on the surface of cleaning and packaging equipment. In particular, microbial biofilm formation is one of multiple strategies microbial pathogens have used to adhere to and persist on the surface of food products and equipment.

 

Intellectual Merit: We have developed a series of designed enzymes with specificity for common components found in microbial biofilms of common food-borne pathogens such as Salmonella and E. coli. These enzymes can be used in conjunction with, or as a replacement for, common chemical cleaning agents. In this ICORPS project, our team assessed the market potential for these designed enzymes as a green, biocompatible alterative to chemical cleaning agents. Through the process of customer discovery, we identified multiple end-users in specific food processing markets who expressed interest in a enzymatic method for biofilm removal, and gained key insights from them into specific formulations, application methods and uses that would be valuable to have in our product. This informed our laboratory research and development of these enzymes to make them useful in specific end-use applications, as well as identified new market segments where these enzymes would be useful. We also pursued preliminary manufacturing studies of designed enzymes; this was key for identifying costs associated with scale-up in order to develop a realistic business model for our technology.

 

Broader Impacts: The results of this proposal have led to increased partnerships between academia and industry, with an ultimate goal of improved well-being of individuals in society. By working in partnership with industrial end-users, we have been able to develop our technology further with a specific focus towards useful applications we had not originally anticipated, as well as learning from our industrial partners what some of the specific challenges in the food processing industry are. Furthermore, this work was completed as part of educational training towards an MBA for the entrepreneurial lead, thereby providing hands-on, translational research to put graduate coursework in a practical context. Lastly, multiple undergraduate students participated in development and refinement of enzymes based on end-user feedback; exposure to the ICORPS method was valuable for engineering undergraduates to see how technology derived from basic science research can be commercialized, and how such a process works.
